verses.text: I waited patiently for the LORD, and He turned to me and heard my cry.
verses.comment: The theme of patient waiting on God is echoed throughout the Psalms. The verbal root has an ongoing sense of 'waiting intensely.'

verses.text: He lifted me up out of a horrible pit, out of the miry clay, and set my feet upon a rock, making my steps secure.
verses.comment: This deliverance symbolizes both rescue from distress and spiritual renewal—a foreshadowing of Christ lifting humanity from sin (see John 3:14–17).

verses.text: He put a new song in my mouth, a song of praise to our God. Many will see and fear, and trust in the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘New song’ indicates a new work of grace; this inspires faith in others, reflecting Christian witness and the call to evangelization.

verses.text: Blessed is the man who makes the LORD his trust, and does not turn to the proud, nor to those who go astray after lies.
verses.comment: Turning from arrogance and falsehood to trust is essential for authentic discipleship, as reinforced by Jesus in Matthew 7:13–14.

verses.text: O LORD my God, You have done many wonders; Your thoughts toward us cannot be recounted; if I declare and speak of them, they are too many to count.
verses.comment: The psalmist contemplates God’s providential care—prefiguring Christ’s own recognition of the Father’s works (cf. John 5:19).

verses.text: Sacrifice and offering You did not desire, but You have opened my ears. Burnt offering and sin offering You did not require.
verses.comment: This verse is cited in Hebrews 10 as pointing to Christ’s fulfillment of the Law, where true obedience surpasses ritual—highlighting the value of interior conversion, a key Catholic doctrine.

verses.text: Then I said, 'Behold, I have come; in the scroll of the book it is written of me.'
verses.comment: Here is a prophetic anticipation, ultimately fulfilled in Christ, who is the eternal Word—the only one able to perfectly obey God's will. Note the connection to scripture as a living tradition.

verses.text: I delight to do Your will, O my God; Your law is within my heart.
verses.comment: The delight in God’s will prefigures Christ’s obedience (see John 4:34) and points to the sanctifying power of God’s grace written on the heart.

verses.text: I have proclaimed good news of righteousness in the great assembly; behold, I have not restrained my lips, O LORD, You know.
verses.comment: Proclaiming God's righteousness foreshadows the mission of the apostles and the public nature of the Church’s witness.

verses.text: I have not hidden Your righteousness within my heart; I have declared Your faithfulness and Your salvation; I have not concealed Your lovingkindness and truth from the great assembly.
verses.comment: Bringing God’s salvation to the assembly foreshadows the liturgical life of the Church—especially the Eucharist as the public proclamation of salvation.

verses.text: Do not withhold Your mercy from me, O LORD; let Your steadfast love and Your faithfulness continually preserve me.
verses.comment: The prayer for God’s unfailing love (‘hesed’) recalls His everlasting covenant—fulfilled perfectly in Christ.

verses.text: For evils beyond number surround me; my iniquities have overtaken me, so that I cannot see; they are more than the hairs of my head, and my heart fails me.
verses.comment: An open confession of personal sin, paralleling Christian repentance and sacramental confession (see James 5:16).

verses.text: Be pleased, O LORD, to deliver me; O LORD, make haste to help me.
verses.comment: The urgency of the plea is echoed in the prayers of both Christ (Gethsemane) and the Church (the Liturgy of the Hours).

verses.text: Let those who seek to destroy my life be put to shame and confounded together; let those who desire my harm be turned back in dishonor.
verses.comment: This prayer for vindication anticipates Christ’s own sufferings and the ultimate justice God grants those who trust in Him (cf. 2 Thess. 1:6-7).

verses.text: Let those who say to me, 'Aha! Aha!' be appalled because of their shame.
verses.comment: ‘Aha!’ expresses mockery, which Christ Himself faced (Mark 15:29). His suffering gives meaning to the righteous who are mocked for their faith.

verses.text: Let all who seek You rejoice and be glad in You; let those who love Your salvation say continually, 'The LORD be magnified!'
verses.comment: Joy in God’s salvation is the destiny of all believers—a call to worship echoed in the Church’s liturgy (see Revelation 19:5-7).

verses.text: But I am poor and needy; yet the Lord thinks of me. You are my help and my deliverer; O my God, do not delay.
verses.comment: The psalm closes with humility and dependence on God, a central Catholic virtue echoed in the Magnificat (Luke 1:46-55), where Mary exalts the Lord as her savior.
